hints.content: Start by understanding the definition of a 132 pattern. You need to find three indices i, j, and k such that i < j < k and the values at these indices satisfy nums[i] < nums[k] < nums[j].

Consider the constraints of the problem. You are given an array of integers with a length between 1 and 200,000, and each integer can range from -10^9 to 10^9. Think about how this might affect your approach.

Think about how you can iterate through the array. A brute force approach would involve checking all combinations of i, j, and k, but this would be inefficient (O(n^3)). Can you think of a more efficient way to check for the pattern?

Focus on the relationship between the three numbers in the pattern. If you can find a way to keep track of potential candidates for nums[i] and nums[k] while iterating through nums[j], it might simplify your search.

Consider using a stack to help manage the potential candidates for nums[k]. As you iterate through the array, you can maintain a stack of values that could serve as nums[k] while ensuring they are less than nums[j].

When using a stack, remember that you want to maintain the property that nums[k] is the largest possible value that is still less than nums[j]. Think about how you can pop elements from the stack to maintain this condition.
As you iterate through the array from right to left, keep track of the maximum value that could be nums[k]. This will help you determine if you can find a valid nums[i] for the current nums[j].

While iterating, if you find a value that is less than the current maximum (potential nums[k]), check if it is greater than the last value popped from the stack. This will help you verify the 132 pattern.
Make sure to handle edge cases, such as arrays with less than three elements. In such cases, you should return false immediately since a 132 pattern cannot exist.

Finally, consider the return value. You should return true as soon as you find a valid 132 pattern, and false if you finish iterating without finding one. Think about how you will structure your loop and conditions to achieve this.

The values must satisfy nums[i] < nums[k] < nums[j].
Return true if a 132 pattern exists, otherwise return false.
